div1.p: These are Public Health Service specifications for impounded waters in malarial areas; autograph notes added.

div1.head: Report fragment: Impounded Waters, [1921?]
div1.p:

1. Wherever impounded water projects are to be located
under the provisions of this act in those parts of the United
States in which malarial fevers exist or malaria bearing mos-
quitoes are known to propagate, the following general measures
shall be enforced for the protection of the public health:

(a) In the area to be occupied by the reservoir, its
branches and identations, all brush, trees, under-
growth, logs and similar objects, which if not re-
moved would float on the surface of the impounded
water and thus constitute conditions favorable to
the production of malaria mosquitoes, shall be re-
moved, burned or otherwise disposed of prior to the
closing of the dam and impounding the water.

(b) In the area to be occupied by the reservoir, its
branches and indentations, all stumps of trees or
under-brush shall be cut sufficiently near to the
surface of the ground to prevent their standing
above the surface of the water at any and all stages
of the water, and thus holding drift and floatage.

Walter
water sh'd pass
over the dam (so as to carry off, drift & floatage) especially during freshets

(c) The formation of log jams and the collection of
drift and floatage in narrow valleys or indenta-
tions of the reservoir where wave action is absent
or weak shall be prevented.

(d) In so far as practicable, the water level in the
reservoir shall be fixed so as to reduce to a mini-
mum shallow, submerged areas on which aquatic plants
will grow and reach the surface of the water.

High during the
winter lower
during summer

(e) The reservoir shall be stocked with top minnows which
feed upon mosquito larvae and every effort shall be
made to protect them against their enemies and secure
their successful propagation

2. Wherever an impounded water project is to be located
under the provisions of the Act aforesaid in any part of the
United States, the licensee shall carry out such measures as an
officer of the Public Health Service designated by the Commission
may determine to be necessary in each case to prevent pollution
of the drainage shed and the water of the reservoir with excreta
or other refuse matter likely to cause or aggravate a nuisance
or danger to the health of persons living near the reservoir or
dependent in any way upon the water in or flowing from the
reservoir.

3. The foregoing rules and regulations may be amended from
time to time as necessary within the discretion of the Commission.
